articles.headline: New Questions Swirl Over Boeing on Updated 737 Model That Crashed
articles.snippet: The airplane manufacturer did not provide airlines and pilots with full information about a new emergency system on the plane.
articles.abstract: The airplane manufacturer did not provide airlines and pilots with full information about a new emergency system on the plane.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Boeing faced new scrutiny on Tuesday over the crash of one of its planes into the sea off Indonesia last month, as airlines, pilots and regulators sought to determine whether the company had underplayed the complexity of a new emergency system suspected of having malfunctioned on the doomed jetliner.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech, Hiroko Tabuchi, James Glanz and Zach Wichter

articles.headline: With Hoopla and Murals, Crystal City Welcomes Amazon
articles.snippet: Crystal City, a declining neighborhood in Arlington, Va., cheered Amazon’s arrival on Tuesday. It’s getting a new name — National Landing — to go along with its victory.
articles.abstract: Crystal City, a declining neighborhood in Arlington, Va., cheered Amazon’s arrival on Tuesday. It’s getting a new name — National Landing — to go along with its victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Over the past few months, murals had started appearing on a fence surrounding an empty brick warehouse in the Crystal City neighborhood of Arlington. Sporting geometric shapes and adorned with hanging bicycles, the murals also displayed aspirational slogans in big black letters like “What If?” and “Why Not?”
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: A Fugitive Financier’s Charm Offensive Has P.R. Firms Proceeding With Caution
articles.snippet: Jho Low is accused of masterminding the disappearance of more than $2.7 billion in Malaysia. Firms representing him are being careful amid scrutiny of foreign influence efforts.
articles.abstract: Jho Low is accused of masterminding the disappearance of more than $2.7 billion in Malaysia. Firms representing him are being careful amid scrutiny of foreign influence efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: A flamboyant Malaysian financier who once hosted Hollywood parties and lavished gifts on models is on a new kind of charm offensive.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: A Search in Fire-Ravaged California for What No One Wants to Find
articles.snippet: In the Northern California town of Paradise, specialists are scouring burned homes for the scores of people still unaccounted for.
articles.abstract: In the Northern California town of Paradise, specialists are scouring burned homes for the scores of people still unaccounted for.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARADISE, Calif. — It is a measure of how frequent and deadly wildfires have become in California that identifying badly burned remains has become an area of expertise. Once again cadaver dogs have been summoned, forensic dental experts will follow and coroners and anthropologists are using their experience from previous wildfires to locate the victims.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: A $2 Billion Question: Did New York and Virginia Overpay for Amazon?
articles.snippet: The states offered tax credits, rebates and other incentives to lure the online retail giant and 25,000 jobs. Neighboring states offered even more.
articles.abstract: The states offered tax credits, rebates and other incentives to lure the online retail giant and 25,000 jobs. Neighboring states offered even more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon built a retail empire on low prices and free shipping. But for taxpayers, its new headquarters didn’t come cheap.

articles.headline: Melania Trump Says an Aide ‘No Longer Deserves the Honor of Serving in This White House’
articles.snippet: There were conflicting reports on Tuesday on whether Mira Ricardel, a deputy national security adviser, had been fired.
articles.abstract: There were conflicting reports on Tuesday on whether Mira Ricardel, a deputy national security adviser, had been fired.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She bad-mouthed the defense secretary. She was the hatchet woman for John R. Bolton, the famously combative national security adviser, and drove out staff members from the National Security Council who were deemed insufficiently conservative or loyal.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Helene Cooper and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Brexit Could Leave Wedding Bouquets Stuck at the Border
articles.snippet: From greenhouses in Kenya to auction houses in the Netherlands to florists in London, the shipment of flowers highlights Brexit’s potential disruption to trade.
articles.abstract: From greenhouses in Kenya to auction houses in the Netherlands to florists in London, the shipment of flowers highlights Brexit’s potential disruption to trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Far removed from the political posturing and brinkmanship that capture most of the attention in Britain’s long and tedious departure from the European Union, Yme Pasma is deeply enmeshed in the mother of all logistical problems.

articles.headline: How Google Photos Became a Perfect Jukebox for Our Memories
articles.snippet: Google Photos, introduced in 2015, has become one of the most emotionally resonant pieces of technology today. It is also shaping our narratives along the way.
articles.abstract: Google Photos, introduced in 2015, has become one of the most emotionally resonant pieces of technology today. It is also shaping our narratives along the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first time Google Photos made me cry, it was with a sucker punch.

articles.headline: Behind Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s Rise, Two Loyal Enforcers
articles.snippet: The killing of Jamal Khashoggi has focused attention on two aides to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who have played key roles in his aggressive acts.
articles.abstract: The killing of Jamal Khashoggi has focused attention on two aides to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who have played key roles in his aggressive acts.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia convened an outdoor banquet this spring for his fellow Arab rulers, seated among the kings, princes and presidents were two friends with few qualifications other than their closeness to the young prince himself: a poet who has become known for orchestrating ferocious social media campaigns, and a former security guard who runs the Saudi sports commission.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Amazon’s New York Home Qualifies as ‘Distressed’ Under Federal Tax Law
articles.snippet: The Long Island City site was designated as an “opportunity zone,” an incentive created by President Trump’s tax bill to help low-income areas attract investment.
articles.abstract: The Long Island City site was designated as an “opportunity zone,” an incentive created by President Trump’s tax bill to help low-income areas attract investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are wine bars and a cycling studio along the riverfront in Long Island City, among gleaming high-rise apartment buildings with views of Midtown Manhattan. The soon-to-open library branch is a modern art cube of concrete, the median income is $138,000 a year, and America’s hottest online retailer is about to move in.

articles.headline: Trump Embraces a Path to Revise U.S. Sentencing and Prison Laws
articles.snippet: Senators have staked the success of the bipartisan agreement on President Trump, but powerful pockets of opposition remain among some law enforcement officials and conservative lawmakers.
articles.abstract: Senators have staked the success of the bipartisan agreement on President Trump, but powerful pockets of opposition remain among some law enforcement officials and conservative lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump threw his support behind  a substantial revision of the nation’s prison and sentencing laws on Wednesday, opening a potential path to enacting the most significant changes to the criminal justice system in a generation.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Maggie Haberman
